title: An Unexpected Cause of Sudden Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I woke up in the ICU and noticed I couldn't hear well in either ear, though the left is worse. I also have ringing in my ears and everything sounds distorted.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset approximately 2.5 weeks prior to the initial visit, noticed upon regaining consciousness in the ICU.
problem_summary.course: Sudden onset followed by some spontaneous recovery in the right ear over 2 months; left ear remained poor with fluctuation.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bilateral tinnitus (louder in left), blurry vision, decreased cognition, weakness, aphasia, fever. Later developed vertigo and diplacusis (tin-can distortion).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty receiving speech, especially in the left ear. Sound distortion and diplacusis.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient is monitoring recovery; initially too weak for surgery/interventions.

history.present_illness: Patient hospitalized for 2 weeks with encephalitis. Upon waking, noted bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. Also reports 30 lb weight loss.
history.otologic_history: No history of hearing loss prior to hospitalization. Right parotid Warthin's tumor (no surgery).
history.noise_exposure_history: History of noise exposure from working as a farmer for many years.
history.medical_psych_history: Atrial fibrillation, diabetes. Recent ICU stay for encephalitis.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: slight sloping to severe SNHL. Left ear: moderately severe to severe flat SNHL.

numeric_results.Right_AC_Thresholds: Sloping from ~20 dB HL at 250 Hz to ~80 dB HL at 8000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Slight loss in SRT for right ear; moderately severe loss for left ear. WRS showed slight difficulty in right ear and very poor ability in left ear.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent bilaterally in response to ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation.

history.present_illness: Follow-up 2 months later. Patient reports improved hearing, strength, and balance. Diagnosed with West Nile Virus (WNV).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Significant improvement; normal sensitivity (250-1000 Hz) sloping to moderate SNHL (2-3k Hz) rising to mild (6-8k Hz). Left ear: Slight sloping to severe SNHL (250-8000 Hz).

numeric_results.Right_Improvement: Improved by 15 dB @ 250 Hz; 20 dB @ 500/4000 Hz; 25 dB @ 1000 Hz
numeric_results.Left_Thresholds: Remains severe in highs, some low freq improvement

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear SRT improved. Left ear SAT obtained. WRS very poor in left ear.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral: Normal at 500/1000 Hz, absent at 2000/4000 Hz bilaterally. Contralateral: Elevated or absent.

history.present_illness: Follow-up 9 months later. Reports otalgia (right), diplacusis/distortion (left), and constant ringing tinnitus (left). Reports vertigo when getting out of bed.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo) at this visit.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Stable since last visit. Left ear: Slight sloping to severe SNHL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal ability. Left ear moderately severe loss in ability to receive speech and very poor recognition.

tests.name: Dix-Hallpike test
tests.key_findings: Positive for right benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, initially severe bilaterally but showing significant spontaneous recovery in the right ear. The left ear exhibits a permanent moderately severe to severe sensorineural hearing loss with very poor word recognition scores (16-32%) and diplacusis. The hearing loss is attributed to West Nile Virus encephalitis.
counseling_points: Explain that West Nile Virus can cause inflammation affecting the hearing nerve, which explains the sudden hearing loss.
Discuss the asymmetry: your right ear has recovered significantly, but the left ear has permanent damage and distortion.
Address the 'tin can' sound (diplacusis) in the left ear; this is due to the inner ear damage causing pitch mismatch.
Review the BPPV diagnosis for the dizziness and confirm the Epley maneuver was performed to treat it.
notes_for_actor: In the first visit, you are recovering from encephalitis: act weak, slightly confused, and report significant difficulty hearing.
In the final visit, complain about the 'tin can' sound in your left earâ€”it makes music or voices sound strange.
Mention that the ringing in your left ear fluctuates and bothers you.
